column5: I first saw it when I was 21. Loved it. Just started rewatching it and it‚Äôs really still quite lovely and resonating.

‚ÄúBetter‚Äù is so subjective. I feel like I can‚Äôt avoid this debate. It happens all the time with the ‚ÄúDegrassi‚Äù crowd. 

You realize season 1 was great but so awkward and rough Antoine the edges and odd in a lot of ways. You know that the creators formed a team of mostly early 20‚Äôs writers who didn‚Äôt know how to juggle tv story long form so they decided to come up with the idea of only focusing on one character per episode? (Don‚Äôt get me wrong, it‚Äôs actually one of my favorite things about the show) 

Season 2 had a lot of great things going for it. But season 3 and 4 also had some great episodes and moments. That‚Äôs part of the problem with each episode being about just one character - it can feel really imbalanced. 

No single season of Skins is flawless. There‚Äôs good and there‚Äôs bad. There‚Äôs insane and ridiculous. 

The last generation, I know people didn‚Äôt love it, but it also had some good storytelling towards the end of season 5 and throughout season 6. 

Skins was never a perfect show. In fact, sometimes it‚Äôs hard to go back to the first season, and I say that as someone who grew up loving the show. Thank god it just didn‚Äôt follow the first gen for 6 seasons. That would‚Äôve been awful.

Other than some weird and bizarre things around season 6 and 7, where there were things they would *slightly* edit around. For example, Ashley and Jimmy attempting to have sex while he was in the wheelchair, the original Canadian broadcast showed the full thing, while iTunes/American broadcast would shave off seconds to not spend too much time on the sexy stuff. 

Also, the vending machines or beverages and stuff. I would assume it had to do with legal differences between Canada and the us. If you watch degrassi on an American streaming platform, there are times where you‚Äôll just see the brand names blurred out. 

That‚Äôs it.

Yeah, Degrassi is a wonderful show. But it is never a show that thought FORWARDS about their characters and their arcs. They weren‚Äôt ‚Äúplanning‚Äù on Emma having an eating disorder for 5 seasons. But that every new season they‚Äôd sit there with a bunch of issues they wanted to explore, and all the characters on the board, and said ‚Äúwhere would it be logical for these characters to fall into these issues‚Äù and such. It was a very logical decision for Emma to fit into that. But it wasn‚Äôt premeditated.

One of my best friends is deaf, and it‚Äôs infuriating to me when they‚Äôre out and about with a translator and then the employee or whatever only speaks to the translator. 

Because I‚Äôve become aware of it, I will always in my own experience, speak to the deaf person. And then if they translate then the information always comes acrosss. 

I mean it‚Äôs always the same when I have Spanish-only speaking customers. If they have a family member that speaks English, I will make sure that I‚Äôm paying attention to most of them. And always giving eye contact with the main customer. I don‚Äôt understand why other people don‚Äôt do this.
